title: Lesson 16: Abstract Vector Spaces
objectives: Recognize the derivative as a linear transformation

cards.front: What makes something a vector in abstract linear algebra?
cards.back:
Any object where vector addition and scalar multiplication are sensible operations that satisfy certain axioms.

The form doesn't matter - arrows, lists of numbers, functions, etc. Only the operations matter.

cards.front: How can functions be viewed as vectors?
cards.back:
Functions can be added: (f + g)(x) = f(x) + g(x)
Functions can be scaled: (cf)(x) = c·f(x)

These operations parallel coordinate-wise operations on traditional vectors.

cards.front: Why is the derivative a linear transformation?
cards.back:
It satisfies both properties of linearity:

1. d/dx(f + g) = d/dx(f) + d/dx(g)
2. d/dx(cf) = c·d/dx(f)

The derivative takes functions (vectors) to functions (vectors) in a linear way.

cards.front: What are the vector space axioms for?
cards.back:
They form a checklist ensuring that definitions of addition and scalar multiplication are "reasonable."

If your objects satisfy the axioms, all of linear algebra's theorems apply to them automatically.

cards.front: Why is the abstract view of vectors powerful?
cards.back:
It unifies diverse mathematical objects under one framework.

Results proven for abstract vector spaces apply to arrows, coordinate lists, functions, polynomials, matrices, and more.
